intro: Houstonia longifolia var. ciliolata, commonly known as the hairy bluebells, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped blue or purple flowers. The variety ciliolata is distinguished by its hairy stems and leaves, which give it a unique texture. It typically grows in moist, sandy soils in open woodlands and pine flatwoods. The plant is well adapted to the humid climate of its native range and is often found in shaded to partially shaded environments.
